name: Temiloluwa O. Prioleau
content: t-prioleau.comSearch this siteEmbedded FilesSkip to main contentSkip to navigationAbout MeTemiloluwa PrioleauAssistant Professor, Computer Science Emory UniversityEmail: tpriole@emory.eduI am an Assistant Professor in the Department of Computer Science at Emory University. My research centers around digital and computational health, the use of mobile/wearable technology, and advanced data analytics to develop human-centered computing solutions that enable personalized health. I direct the Augmented Health Lab - a consortium of interdisciplinary researchers working together to tackle grand challenges in healthcare. I am also a core faculty with Emory Global Diabetes Research Center at Emory University, and a faculty affiliate with the Center for Technology and Behavioral Health (CTBH) at Dartmouth College.Open Positions: I am actively recruiting new Ph.D. students to join the my research team. Prospective applicants should apply to the Emory CSI PhD program. I also encourage interested applicants to reach out to me directly via email (tpriole@emory.edu) before applying AND list me as a potential advisor on their application.I was previously an assistant professor in the department of computer science at Dartmouth College and continue to be a research assistant professor in the department. Before joining Dartmouth, I was a Postdoctoral Fellow in the Scalable Health Labs at Rice University. I obtained my M.S. & Ph.D. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from Georgia Institute of Technology, and my B.Sc. also in Electrical and Computer Engineering from The University of Texas at Austin.Recent News2025July - Spotlight article on the DiaTrend dataset and Glucose-ML collection published by Emory Global Diabetes Research Center (EGDRC)July - Joined the Computer Science Department at Emory University.May - Our paper "One Size Does Not Fit All: The Need for Sex-Specific Precision Medicine in Diabetes Technology" was published. Congrats to the Diabetes Center Berne team and the larger team of experts in the field.April - Our paper "Seasonal, weekly, and individual variations in long-term use of wearable medical devices for diabetes management" was published in Scientific Reports.March - June: Visiting faculty with Emory Global Diabetes Research Center (EGDRC)February - Our DiaTrend project was selected for the Dartmouth OSCARRs award (Open Scholarship Commitment Award for Reproducible Research).February - Our paper "Empowering Self-Management of Diabetes through Long-Term Wearable Data and Seasonal Visualizations" was accepted to CHI 2025 as a Late Breaking Work. Congrats to Yanjun Cui and the team!February - Our paper "Clinical Evaluation of a Polarization-Based Optical Noninvasive Glucose Sensing System" was accepted to Scientific Reports. Congrats to Colman Leung and the team.2024August - Our paper "Mealtime Prediction using Wearable Insulin Pump Data to Support Diabetes Management" was accepted for publication at Scientific Reports.July - Our REFLECT2D project was funded by the NIH. The goal of this work is to develop and evaluate a digital health intervention for adolescents and young adults with type 2 diabetes. Congrats to the amazing team and PI Vajravelu.July - Gave an Invited Talk to EMBS YP (Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Young Professionals).February - Gave an Invited Talk to the endocrine department at Dartmouth Health.2023September - Our work on Seasonal Patterns in Diabetes Care was featured in Dartmouth News and 10+ other media outlets such as Verve Times and Tech Explorist.September - Our paper "Understanding Temporal Changes and Seasonal Variations in Glycemic Trends using Wearable Data" was published in Science Advances (impact factor: 13.6).August - Our paper "DiaTrend: A dataset from Advanced Diabetes Technology to Enable Development of Novel Analytic Solutions" was published in Scientific Data.July - Gave an invited talk to the Texas A&M Research for Undergraduates in Computer Science and Data Science program.June - Gave an invited talk at Dartmouth Health on Leveraging Digital Technology and Data Science to Understand and Transform Disease Management.March - Released our first open source dataset - DiaTrend - to advance research & development of novel analytic solutions for diabetes and beyond.See more news!2022November - Taught a mini-course on "Computing for Healthcare" as part of the Dartmouth Adventures in STEM program.July - Gave an invited talk on "Opportunistic Use of Digital Devices and Data to Improve Diabetes Care" at IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Conference 2022.May - Gave an invited talk for Women's History Month at NSF PATHS-UP.March - Our paper "A Hybrid Approach to Realizing Personalized Healthcare" was accepted to CHI 2022 workshop on "Grand Challenges for Personal Informatics and AI".January -
